title: Lorina Papali'i
text:
Lorina Papali'i (born 16 January 1977) is a former New Zealand <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> and <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> footballer from the 1990s, 2000s and 2010s.
A <a href="dual%20international">dual international</a>, she represented <a href="Kiwi%20Ferns">New Zealand</a> in <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> and <a href="Samoa%20women%27s%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Samoa</a> in <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a>.
Background.
Born in <a href="Hamilton%2C%20New%20Zealand">Hamilton, New Zealand</a>, Papali'i went to school in <a href="Newcastle%2C%20Australia">Newcastle, Australia</a> before returning to New Zealand. Her son, <a href="Isaiah%20Papali%27i">Isaiah</a>, is a <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">New Zealand</a> and <a href="Samoa%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Samoan</a> rugby league international.
Playing career.
Rugby league.
In 1994, Papali'i made her Test debut for <a href="Kiwi%20Ferns">New Zealand</a> while playing for the <a href="Richmond%20Rovers">Richmond Rovers</a>. She was later a member of New Zealand's successful <a href="2000%20Women%27s%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">2000</a> and <a href="2003%20Women%27s%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">2003 Women's Rugby League World Cup</a> squads.
Papali'i enjoyed a long career with Richmond, winning the club's Player of the Year award four times (1996, 1997, 2001, 2002) and Forward of the Year award three times (1994, 1995, 2003). In 2002, she won the New Zealand Women's Nationals Player of the Tournament and in 2004 won the <a href="NZRL">NZRL</a> Player of the Year. In 2010, she retired from rugby.
On 1 August 2018, Papali'i came out of retirement and was named in the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Warriors">New Zealand Warriors</a> <a href="NRL%20Women%27s%20Premiership">NRL Women's Premiership</a> squad.
In Round 1 of the <a href="2018%20NRL%20Women%27s%20season">2018 NRL Women's season</a>, she made her debut for the Warriors in a 10–4 win over the <a href="Sydney%20Roosters">Sydney Roosters</a>. In doing so, Papali'i and her son <a href="Isaiah%20Papali%27i">Isaiah</a> (who played for the Warriors' men's team) became the first mother and son to play for the same club.
Rugby union.
In <a href="2002%20Women%27s%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2002</a> and <a href="2006%20Women%27s%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2006</a>, Papali'i represented <a href="Samoa%20women%27s%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Samoa</a> at the <a href="Rugby%20World%20Cup%20%28women%27s%29">Rugby World Cup</a>.
